Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Collaborative Research: Deciphering the Structure and Evolution of North America?s Cratonic Core
Award.AbstractNarration:
This project seeks to illuminate the formation, assembly and subsequent evolution of the US mid-continent. Investigators at two universities and their graduate and undergraduate students will examine composition of the mid-continent crust and upper mantle. A novel combination of gravity and magnetic data with seismic velocity ratios vP/vS estimated from seismic receiver function data and velocity structure from surface wave and body wave tomography will be used to establish variations in temperature as well as thickness and bulk composition of multiple layers within the crust. The novel elements of these efforts include development of a new approach to receiver function imaging using parameter-domain cross-correlation and stacking, and coupling of the seismic images to the potential field data via likelihood filters and velocity-density relationships. Magnetic studies will focus also on understanding the physical properties and tectonic implications of magnetically detected boundaries, with particular emphases on a hidden middle Proterozoic geochemical and magnetic boundary dividing the cratonic core of North America and also on the Tennessee-Illinois-Kentucky lineament (or TIKL) and its unusual banded pattern of magnetization. The geophysical model results will be combined with sparsely sampled basement isotope geochemistry and age data to interpret the history of formation and accretion of lithospheric blocks as well as their subsequent tectonomagmatic modification.

Knowledge about physical properties of the crust and its history of tectonism and volcanism is central to a wide array of solid Earth science topics. Assessments of the likelihood of future earthquakes and the potential for economic mineral deposits at depth are just two examples of applications in which such knowledge plays a vital societal role. In order to evaluate better these risks and economic potential, a multi-disciplinary project involving professors and graduate and undergraduate students at two universities will seek to understand key structures, composition and processes that formed the geologic core of the US mid-continent. In mountainous regions of the western US, mapping variations in physical properties and inferring tectonic history are relatively straightforward because geophysical images of the deep crust and uppermost mantle can be corroborated by studies of rocks exposed and/or brought to the surface by geologic processes. In the mid-continent region of the US however, thick sequences of sedimentary rocks cover the ancient rocks produced by episodes of magmatism. Boreholes reaching below the sedimentary cover are few and far between and that has made it challenging to understand the geologic past that may control the locations of earthquakes and hidden mineral deposits. Consequently, tectonic and seismic hazard maps of this region rely more heavily on geophysical lineaments: linear features found in map-views of geophysical data sets signifying geologic boundaries and weak zones. This study seeks to combine several different types of geophysical data sets, including gravity and magnetic anomalies as well as images made possible by EarthScope?s array of seismometers. The previously unknown characteristics of the mid-continent crust derived from these data will be used to better characterize implications of the geologic boundaries for understanding comprehensively the history and properties of the Earth?s outer layers.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The details of geologic and tectonic framework, timing of tectonic activity of North America, and geophysical methods of locating resources are important for resource exploration, estimation, and production.  The older the region, the more difficult it is to decipher its tectonic framework and the greater the amount of peripheral geologic information one needs (e.g., outcrops and drillhole samples of rocks, their ages, how they formed, and where they came from).  The geologic evidence related to the accretion of landmasses of Paleoproterozoic (older than 1.55 billion years ago) and Mesoproterozoic (younger than 1.55 billion years ago) times and granite-rhyolite magmatism (1.45 and 1.35 billion years ago) in the central U.S. and its deep structure – the topic of this study – is buried under thick deposits of sedimentary rocks. During this study, we found that only magnetic and geochemical data show well the 1.55 billion year old boundary between the Paleoproterozoic and Mesoproterozoic provinces.  The Paleoproterozoic provinces are associated with a zone of very high magnetization. We had previously thought, following conventional knowledge about where in the crust the layers of high and low magnetization may lie, that the high magnetization of Paleoproterozoic provinces must be in the lower crust. However, one of the biggest surprises of this study was that the depth to the base of magnetization (from a new method we developed during this study) is in the middle of the crust, instead of magnetization extending to the bottom of the crust. The finding makes it necessary to have high magnetization in the middle crust and this has implications on the origin of the Paleoproterozoic domain. We place the high magnetization of Paleoproterozoic provinces in the context of models of geophysical structure of the lithosphere developed from other geophysical data sets such as the thickness of the sedimentary rocks, gravity field, and seismology. The high magnetization zone over the Paleoproterozoic provinces suggests that the subduction direction at the boundary between the Paleoproterozoic and Mesoproterozoic provinces could be westward, contrary to the prevalent geochemical models which inferred eastward subduction.  

We developed several new geophysical techniques during this project to decipher the geologic origin of the Paleoproterozoic-Mesoproterozoic boundary and enigmatic granite-rhyolite magmatism in the central U.S. Many of these techniques are also useful for exploration of resources (for example, we developed three new methods for locating magnetic sources). Additional two new methods we developed in this study to detect the base of the magnetic layer in the Earth’s crust can also determine temperatures deep in the crust. Incorporation of this temperature into the theory of steady state heat flow (1 new method developed) allows us to extract estimate of radiogenic heat production which in turn is useful for determining petroleum maturation in the sedimentary rocks above, mineral resources potential of a region, and, when the heat generation is high, the geothermal energy potential of the region. All these new methods are applicable globally.

The project also provided opportunities for four graduate students to become proficient in using geophysical techniques, understanding how to validate the results internally and with external datasets, computer programming, using and configuring Unix/Linux computer operating systems, and to complete their master’s degrees. Work is still underway on two additional research papers related to the project and the report will be updated when those are published.
